Western Maryland
Ducats Go On Sale

This past Sunday 177 men, representing an increase of 25% over
last year's total of 142, entered
bids for the twelve Interfraternity
Board fraternities.
Out of this total, 145 were accepted, as compared with 120 for
last November.
This year was heralded as one
of crisis for the fraternity system
here at Hopkins because of a
possible "new plan" influence
upon student interests.
After announcing the
bids
to fraternity representatives Sunday, Charles Hoffman, IFB president, said, "This increase seems
to dispell the idea that the academic pace of the new plan students would bring about .a breakdown or at least a radical change
in the Hopkins fraternity system."

H-Club Stays
Independent
Following a dispute about the
handling of H-Club funds, the
members of the athletic group
voted on October 28 not to join
the SAC.
Statements by leaders of the
organizations involved gave eonflicting opinions on the decision.
"The H Club didn't join the SAC
simply because there was no special reason to," said Bill Maginnis,
H Club President.
In contrast to this, Arthur Sarnoff, Vice-President of the SAC
said that the Club didn't join because it probably felt that the SAC
would take away its independence..
Sarnoff stated that the SAC's only
desire was to help keep the H-Club
out of any financial trouble. If
the club were to run at a deficit,
he felt that the school would have
to fopt the bill, and that he wanted to avoid such a situation.
Maginnis, of course, felt that
the Club could take care of itself,
but he left the door open by saying
that it might join next year. "It
depends on next year's members;
if they vote to join, then we'll
join," he said.

official of the H-Club made an

Homewood, Baltimore, November 14, 1952

Hopkins Hosts National
Bookstore Convention
Sunday, November 16, will be
the opening day of the Annual
Southeastern regional meeting of
the National Association of College Stores, to be held in Baltimore.
Johns Hopkins University will
play host to representatives from
some 75 university and college
bookstores located from Maryland
to Florida, and as far -west as Tennessee. This is the first time such
a convention has been held in Baltimore.

up with a trip to the Naval Academy, an oyster roast, and a dance.

tours

of °local

university

stores.

of the Loyola College Store and
Mr. Henry Goodman, manager of
the Hopkins Bookstore, will act
as co-chairmen of the meeting.
Though the count of schools to
be represented is not definite, at
least seventy-five representatives
are expected. The president of
NACL, H. R. Ritchie, from the University of North Carolina is expected.

In last week's election two men

CHRISTIAN HERTER —JHU
Trustee, who was victorious in a
tight Massachusetti gubernatorial
race.
former student was elected Senator from Missouri.
Herter, while serving in 1943
as a trustee of the University organized, and became the head of
the Foreign Service Educational
Foundation. It is this organization
which developed the School of
Advanced International Studies.
During this period he was a member of the House of Representatives. In 1952 Herter was appointed to the House Rules Committee.

All those interested should contact the Y office or write Box 303.

Next Wednesday, Thursday and
Friday, November 19 thru 21, during the lunch hour and at 4:00 at
Levering Hall, the Inter-Varsity
Christian Fellowship will be hayign Captain Cleo W. Buxton to
talk over such practical issues as
sex, love and marriage; what it
means to be a Christian; life in
the army; choosing one's life
work; and social life at college.
During the last war Captain Buxton fought in the Mediterranean
theatre, took part in the invasion
at Anzio, accumulated a record
number of combat days, received
several decorations and was hospitalized over twenty times for
wounds received in action.

THE ANTITHESIS OF BROTHERHOOD

Makin"Yhe Rounds

We learned early this week that during the past rushing

Yes, the nice part about umbrellas is their
similarity. When the need is urgent, any

_ When it comes to telephone equipment,

such rigid standardization made possible
the smooth and interlocking system that
serves you from Penobscot, Maine, to

Pescadero, California.

disaster — from flood, blast or hurricane.

Ducats Go On Sale

This past Sunday 177 men, representing an increase of 25% over
last year's total of 142, entered
bids for the twelve Interfraternity
Board fraternities.
Out of this total, 145 were accepted, as compared with 120 for
last November.
This year was heralded as one
of crisis for the fraternity system
here at Hopkins because of a
possible "new plan" influence
upon student interests.
After announcing the
bids
to fraternity representatives Sunday, Charles Hoffman, IFB president, said, "This increase seems
to dispell the idea that the academic pace of the new plan students would bring about .a breakdown or at least a radical change
in the Hopkins fraternity system."

H-Club Stays
Independent
Following a dispute about the
handling of H-Club funds, the
members of the athletic group
voted on October 28 not to join
the SAC.
Statements by leaders of the
organizations involved gave eonflicting opinions on the decision.
"The H Club didn't join the SAC
simply because there was no special reason to," said Bill Maginnis,
H Club President.
In contrast to this, Arthur Sarnoff, Vice-President of the SAC
said that the Club didn't join because it probably felt that the SAC
would take away its independence..
Sarnoff stated that the SAC's only
desire was to help keep the H-Club
out of any financial trouble. If
the club were to run at a deficit,
he felt that the school would have
to fopt the bill, and that he wanted to avoid such a situation.
Maginnis, of course, felt that
the Club could take care of itself,
but he left the door open by saying
that it might join next year. "It
depends on next year's members;
if they vote to join, then we'll
join," he said.

Homewood, Baltimore, November 14, 1952

Hopkins Hosts National
Bookstore Convention
Sunday, November 16, will be
the opening day of the Annual
Southeastern regional meeting of
the National Association of College Stores, to be held in Baltimore.
Johns Hopkins University will
play host to representatives from
some 75 university and college
bookstores located from Maryland
to Florida, and as far -west as Tennessee. This is the first time such

Trustee, who was victorious in a
tight Massachusetti gubernatorial
race.
former student was elected Senator from Missouri.
Herter, while serving in 1943
as a trustee of the University organized, and became the head of

Foundation. It is this organization
which developed the School of
Advanced International Studies.
During this period he was a member of the House of Representatives. In 1952 Herter was appointed to the House Rules Committee.

Levering Hall, the Inter-Varsity
Christian Fellowship will be hayign Captain Cleo W. Buxton to
talk over such practical issues as
sex, love and marriage; what it
means to be a Christian; life in
the army; choosing one's life
work; and social life at college.
During the last war Captain Buxton fought in the Mediterranean
theatre, took part in the invasion
at Anzio, accumulated a record
number of combat days, received
several decorations and was hospitalized over twenty times for
wounds received in action.

Homewood, Baltimore, November 14, 1952

Admittedly, Joe McCarthy has
received his popular mandate. He
was overwhelmingly nominated
and decisively elected, while his
chief critic, Senator Benton, was
defeated in Connecticut. Now
teamed with McCarran; Vice-President Nixon, a re-elected Jenner,
and a renascent Martin Dies, he
poses as a formidable threat to.
civil liberties. But far from "going
underground," I feel that there is
more need than ever for a stronger, more vigilant SDA to help safeguard those liberties.'
Life goes on, whether the Old
Guard Republicans will admit it
or not. Big Business will continue
to try to grow Bigger, whether
the government takes effective
means to slow it down or not.
But labor unions will also continue to grow and become more
effective, no matter how many
roadblocks Senator Taft throws in
their path. Segregation of races
and religions is on the way out,
whether Governor James Byrnes
